response.answer_text: Yes. Even though she’s officially Dominican, she’s Black. Let me explain: Here’s a clip from Dave Chappelle’s show: The Racial Draft It’s hilarious because it shows different races “claiming” people based on a certain racial factor or because, despite outward appearances, they come from a cultural place closer to another race. Cardi B may not be technically African American, but she is accepted as being from “The Hood” for lack of a better word. She is OF Black Culture, (or perhaps to be more specific New York’s Black Culture.) and for many people that’s good enough. DJ Khaled is Palestinian. Rihanna is from Barbados. But they are generally accepted as “Black”. Even Eminem, clearly White, is generally accepted within in the Black community as “Legit” given both 1) his skills and 2) the environment he grew up in. Robin Thicke and Hall & Oates get the label “Blue-Eyed Soul” and also have many African American fans. The late Teena Marie —who came of age prior to MTV — was long thought to be Black by people who heard her only on the radio. On the other hand, not everyone gets that treatment: Darius Rucker of Hootie and the Blowfish has a largely White fanbase. So too do singers Carly Simon and Halsey who are both part African American. Basically, it’s often more about culture and your genre than just skin color.
